metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of Heihe remote sensing station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Heihe remote sensing station from January 1 to December 31, 2020. The site (100.4756° E, 38.8270° N) was located on artificial grassland in Dangzhai Town of Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1560 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (1.5 m, north), wind speed and direction (10 m, north), air pressure (2 m), rain gauge (0.7 m), four-component radiometer (1.5 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (1.5 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, -1.6 m), and two photosynthetically active radiation (1.5 m, south, one vertically downward and one vertically upward).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_1.5, RH_1.5 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, Ms_160 cm) (℃),on the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. Due to the power loss, data during August 26 to September 18 and October 10 to 17 were missing. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2020-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is an 'eddy covariance system' in the context of data collection for oasis–desert systems?
Definition.Answer: An 'eddy covariance system' is a method used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, which includes measurements of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes within oasis–desert systems.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the data processing and quality control procedures between datasets from automatic weather stations and those acquired by an eddy covariance system?
Comparison.Answer: Both datasets involve rigorous data processing and quality control procedures, including handling missing data, removing duplicates, and ensuring data validity. Automatic weather stations provide data on hydrometeorology with a 10-minute average period, while eddy covariance systems offer half-hourly turbulent flux data, requiring specific processing methods suited to their temporal resolution and data type.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do challenges faced by oasis-desert systems differ from those faced by inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas, and how do these challenges influence data collection strategies?
Comparison.Answer: Oasis-desert systems face challenges related to maintaining ecological and agricultural productivity, which influence data collection to focus on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. Inland river basins face environmental degradation, leading to data collection strategies that monitor ecological changes, such as river drying and land desertification, influencing the scope and type of data collected.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the integration of both artificial and natural oasis-desert system data enhance the understanding of carbon exchange processes in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating data from both artificial and natural oasis-desert systems provides a comprehensive understanding of carbon exchange processes by capturing a wide range of ecological interactions and anthropogenic impacts. This approach can significantly improve insights into the carbon balance and the role of these ecosystems in the global carbon cycle.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: It is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems to achieve sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, supporting ecological security, and ensuring the sustainable development of oases.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges faced in data collection in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face challenges such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These factors contribute to the crisis of ecological environment degradation, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are long-term observations indispensable in understanding oasis–desert interactions for data collection purposes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable because they provide a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas. This understanding is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of implementing long-term observational datasets from oasis-desert systems in addressing the degradation of inland river basins?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing long-term observational datasets from oasis-desert systems can provide a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions. This understanding is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases and can help address issues like river drying, vegetation degradation, and land desertification in inland river basins.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of having a robust dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange for achieving carbon neutrality in oasis-desert areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Having a robust dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange is critical for understanding the carbon dynamics in oasis-desert ecosystems. This knowledge can inform strategies to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems, which is essential for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these areas, supporting ecological security and sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of establishing a comprehensive observation network in the Heihe River Basin for surface process monitoring?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is important for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals, supporting ecological security, and ensuring sustainable development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to implement long-term observation datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, protecting ecological stability, and supporting socioeconomic development in these regions, as well as maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind collecting hydrometeorological data and vegetation parameters in arid regions of western China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives include investigating the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, supporting ecological security, and contributing to the understanding necessary for sustainable oasis development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to ensure the accuracy and quality of meteorological data collected from automatic weather stations in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure involves ensuring a consistent number of data points per day, marking missing data with a specific code, removing duplicate entries, deleting data that exceed physical meaning or instrument range, and marking questionable data in a distinguishable manner. Additionally, the data format is unified, and timestamps are standardized.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are soil temperature and moisture profiles measured and maintained in long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil temperature and moisture profiles are measured using sensors placed at various depths, including 0 cm, 2 cm, 4 cm, 10 cm, 20 cm, 40 cm, 80 cm, 120 cm, and 160 cm. The data are collected at regular intervals and undergo quality control to ensure accuracy. The dataset is supplemented with additional vegetation and soil parameters to provide comprehensive insights.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental techniques are employed to observe energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in the oasis–desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Observational datasets from oasis–desert systems include measurements of energy, water vapor, and carbon and methane fluxes using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers. These datasets are complemented by hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations, providing a detailed overview of the various environmental parameters.

Enablement.Question: What data processing and quality control procedures enable the collection of reliable meteorological and soil data in the oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedures involve ensuring complete daily data collection with 144 data points per day at 10-minute intervals. Missing data are marked with -6999, and issues such as power supply failures are noted. Duplicate records are removed, and data that exceed physical or instrument limits are deleted. Additionally, questionable data are marked in red, and date-time formats are standardized to ensure consistency.

Enablement.Question: What technological systems are used to enable the collection of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert areas?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert areas is enabled through technological systems such as eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, along with automatic weather stations that record hydrometeorological data at 10-minute intervals. These systems provide comprehensive datasets essential for analyzing ecological processes and interactions in these regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might the data collection methods used in oasis–desert ecosystems be expected to provide comprehensive insights into carbon balance and energy exchange?
Expectation.Answer: The data collection methods involve long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which are crucial for understanding oasis–desert interactions. The use of eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations provides detailed data, enabling a quantitative understanding of these processes that support ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Expectation.Question: Why is it crucial to have auxiliary data such as vegetation and soil parameters in datasets observing oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Including auxiliary data such as vegetation and soil parameters is crucial because they provide context for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. These parameters are essential for interpreting how oasis–desert systems interact and contribute to maintaining ecological balance and supporting sustainable development goals in arid regions.

Judgmental.Question: How effectively do automated weather stations capture the complexities of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in arid and semi-arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Automated weather stations are equipped to capture a wide range of meteorological and hydrological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. These stations, providing data with a 10-minute average period, alongside groundwater table data, offer a comprehensive suite of observational datasets crucial for understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert systems.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges are faced in maintaining data quality and consistency for long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in maintaining data quality and consistency include dealing with data loss due to equipment failures or power issues, as seen with the missing data from 8.26-9.18 and 10.10-10.17, and ensuring the accuracy of data by removing duplicates and outliers that exceed physical or instrumental limits. Quality control measures, such as marking suspect data in red and standardizing date-time formats, are employed to address these issues.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways do current dataset collection methods contribute to the understanding of oasis-desert interactions, and what improvements could be made?
Judgmental.Answer: Current dataset collection methods, including the use of eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations, provide a rich dataset covering energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, and auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters. These methods are crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions. Improvements could focus on expanding the spatial coverage of observation stations and integrating newer technologies for data capture and processing to enhance the comprehensiveness and resolution of the collected data.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods in arid and semiarid regions can effectively monitor energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange over long periods.
Assertion.Answer: In arid and semiarid regions, data collection methods involve using a suite of observational datasets that include long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets are obtained through tools like eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the significance of using both artificial and natural systems in data collection for oasis–desert ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Using both artificial and natural systems in data collection is significant because it provides a comprehensive understanding of how these ecosystems function and interact. This approach allows for the observation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in both controlled (artificial) and uncontrolled (natural) environments, aiding in achieving sustainable development and ecological security in oasis areas.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the challenges faced in maintaining long-term meteorological datasets in arid and semiarid regions, particularly in the context of oasis–desert systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include ecological environment degradation such as the drying of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, land desertification, and dust storms. These issues are particularly prevalent in inland river basins along the Silk Road, affecting the continuity and reliability of long-term datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets available for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas and describe their significance.
Request/Directive.Answer: Datasets from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) include energy, water vapor, and carbon flux observations. These datasets are significant for understanding the interactions between oasis and desert systems and are freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, aiding in the study of ecological stability and socioeconomic development in arid regions.
